children.definition: Pro forma total net leverage test at 4.75x, the median threshold across the corpus for builder basket RP usage.
children.name: Standard 4.75x TNL

children.definition: Conservative leverage gate at 3.5x total net leverage, typical in LMM deals with tighter credit profiles.
children.name: Conservative 3.5x
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments)

children.definition: Aggressive leverage gate at 5.0x or higher, seen in UMM/BSL deals with sponsor-friendly terms.
children.name: Aggressive 5.0x+
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: No pro forma leverage test required for builder basket RP usage; most aggressive formulation (17.3% of corpus).
children.name: No Leverage Condition

red_flags.text: Builder basket RP usage with no leverage gate — permits unlimited value extraction regardless of credit deterioration

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Leverage gate expressed as a cushion inside closing date total leverage ratio (e.g., 0.5x-1.0x inside closing TLR).

market_benchmarks.bsl: At closing TLR or no condition
market_benchmarks.umm: At or inside closing TLR (no cushion)

children.name: Cushion Mechanics

children.definition: Pro forma leverage test required before using Available Amount for restricted payments. The level relative to closing TLR is a key negotiation point.

golden_record_refs.representative_text: (e)the Borrower may declare and make Restricted Payments; provided that, (i), the Total Net Leverage Ratio is less than 1.00:1.00 and (ii) the pro forma Liquidity of the Borrower is greater than or eq

children.name: RP Leverage Gate

red_flags.text: Builder basket RP usage with no leverage gate — permits unlimited value extraction regardless of credit deterioration

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Any event of default blocks builder basket RP usage. Conservative standard in LMM/CMM deals.
children.name: Full EoD Blocker
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 7

children.definition: Only bankruptcy or missed payment events of default block RP usage. Typical in UMM/BSL deals, allowing continued distributions during covenant defaults.
children.name: Bankruptcy / Payment EoD Only

red_flags.text: Only bankruptcy/payment EoD blocks RP usage — covenant defaults, cross-defaults, and judgment defaults do not prevent distributions

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Builder basket RP usage permitted even during an event of default. Most aggressive formulation; flagged as high-risk by institutional credit committees.
children.name: No Default Blocker

red_flags.text: No default blocker on Available Amount RP — distributions continue during payment or bankruptcy events of default
Builder basket not subject to EoD blocker -- permits distributions from the Available Amount even during Events of Default

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Event of default condition that must be satisfied before builder basket RP usage. Scope ranges from full EoD to bankruptcy/payment-only to none.

market_benchmarks.bsl: Bankruptcy/payment EoD only or no stopper

children.name: Default Blocker

red_flags.text: No default blocker on Available Amount RP — distributions continue during payment or bankruptcy events of default

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 7

children.definition: Portion of ECF not swept by mandatory prepayment that accumulates in the Available Amount.
children.name: Retained Excess Cash Flow
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Cash equity contributions received after the closing date that accumulate in the builder basket, creating capacity for restricted payments to equity holders. Each qualifying dollar of contributed equity adds to the cumulative builder amount, but contributions applied to contribution debt, equity cure, or other specified purposes are excluded to prevent multi-basket double-counting.
children.name: Equity Contributions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Percentage of cumulative net income (typically 50%) that builds the Available Amount over time. Alternative to retained ECF in some structures.
children.name: CNI Percentage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Net cash proceeds from asset dispositions that are not required to be applied as mandatory prepayments and instead accumulate in the builder basket. These proceeds become available for restricted payments only after the mandatory prepayment waterfall has been satisfied and any reinvestment period has expired, ensuring senior debt service takes priority over equity distributions.
children.name: Asset Sale Proceeds

red_flags.text: Builder basket sources include non-swept asset sale proceeds — creates value leakage path from asset stripping

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 3; Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold); Review Template Row 43 (Asset Sale Sweep – Reinvestment); Review Template Row 44 (Asset Sale Sweep – Stepdowns); Review Template Row 120 (Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Builder)

children.definition: Returns on permitted investments that recycle back into the Available Amount, creating a double-dip leakage channel.
children.name: Investment Returns
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 92 (Negative Covenants – Investments – General Basket); Review Template Row 95 (Negative Covenants – Investments – Other); Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Component sources that feed the Available Amount used for RP capacity. Typically includes retained ECF, equity contributions, and a percentage of cumulative net income.

golden_record_refs.representative_text:
“Cumulative Amount” means, at any time (the “Cumulative Amount Reference Time”), an amount (which shall not be less than zero) equal to, without duplication:

children.name: Builder Sources

red_flags.text: Builder basket sources include non-swept asset sale proceeds — creates value leakage path from asset stripping
Declined ECF sweep proceeds automatically credited to Available Amount without leverage test — bypasses mandatory prepayment protection

children.definition_source: Review Template Row 41 (Asset Sale Sweep - Coverage); Review Template Row 45 (ECF Sweep – Holiday); Review Template Row 47 (ECF Sweep – Threshold)

children.definition: Initial amount of the Available Amount at closing (the 'starter'), providing immediate RP capacity before any builder accumulation occurs.
children.name: Starter Exemption

children.definition: Requirement that no event of default exists or would result from the proposed restricted payment. Scope varies by basket type and market segment.
children.name: No EoD Condition

children.definition: Time period over which the builder basket accumulates (typically from closing date through the most recent test period).
children.name: Measurement Period
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Whether the Available Amount must be tested on a pro forma basis giving effect to the proposed RP and any related transactions.
children.name: Pro Forma Adjustment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: How the retained ECF component interacts with mandatory prepayment calculations. Key risk: AA should not grow from non-swept proceeds (KCT Item 3).
children.name: ECF Sweep Interaction
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 46 (ECF Sweep – Percentages)

children.definition: Rules governing how the Available Amount is computed, including the measurement period, pro forma adjustments, and interaction with ECF sweep calculations.
children.name: Calculation Mechanics
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Condition requiring the borrower to demonstrate pro forma compliance with applicable financial ratios after giving effect to the proposed restricted payment funded from builder basket capacity. Ensures that accumulated builder basket amounts are deployed only when the resulting leverage remains within negotiated thresholds, preventing distributions that would cause covenant deterioration.
children.name: Pro Forma Compliance
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Requirement to maintain minimum cash/revolver availability after the RP. More common in LMM with tighter credit profiles.
children.name: Minimum Liquidity
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 43 (Minimum ratings)

children.definition: Restrictions on using the builder basket simultaneously with other baskets, preventing capacity stacking.
children.name: Concurrent Usage Limits
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Conditions that must be satisfied to draw on the builder basket for restricted payments, beyond the leverage gate and default blocker.
children.name: Usage Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Builder basket providing the largest RP capacity pool, synonymous with the Available Amount. Per Learning Material: 'An important exception in the Restricted Payments covenant is the Builder Basket. In credit agreements, often called the Cumulative Credit or Available Amount. The Builder Basket is usually also permitted to be used for Investments and Restricted Debt Payments.' Formula: Starter + Financial Performance Builder (retained ECF or 50% CNI) + Equity Proceeds + Investment Returns + [Declined Proceeds] + [Retained Asset Sale Proceeds] - Usages. Per DLS Preferred row 86: builder based on retained ECF + equity proceeds, with pro forma leverage compliance required for usage.

golden_record_refs.representative_text:
“Cumulative Amount” means, at any time (the “Cumulative Amount Reference Time”), an amount (which shall not be less than zero) equal to, without duplication:

(i) $25,000,000; plus

children.name: Builder Basket / Available Amount RP

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Does not apply to subsidiaries Other Restricted Payment Baskets: (i) unlimited subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (ii) after and IPO 6% per year of IPO proceeds; variations include, (i) any public equity offerings and (ii) a percentage of market capitalization in lieu of or in addition to the IPO/public equity proceeds (iii) excluded contribution (i.e. cash or other qualified contributions not otherwise applied)

negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Applies to equity of Holdings and all of its subsidiaries (i) so long as no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter, customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory, refinancing, subsequent transaction and exit fees (ii) franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence and other overhead expenses of direct and ind

red_flags.text: Builder basket RP usage with no leverage gate — permits unlimited value extraction regardless of credit deterioration
RP capacity reclassifiable to debt capacity — Available Amount or RP baskets feed incremental equivalent debt

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – high water mark ratchet
Negative Covenants – Available Amount – EoD Blocker
Negative Covenants – Available Amount – Ratio Test

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section 3: 'Builder Basket... often called Cumulative Credit or Available Amount. Usually also permitted to be used for Investments and Restricted Debt Payments.' DLS Preferred row 86.

children.definition: General basket sized as a percentage of Consolidated EBITDA (56.2% of corpus). Grows with earnings performance.
children.name: EBITDA-Based
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 42 (e. Minimum EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: General basket sized as a fixed dollar amount without EBITDA scaling (18.8% of corpus). Common in LMM deals.
children.name: Dollar Cap Only
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Basket sized as the greater of a fixed dollar amount and an EBITDA percentage (2.1% of corpus). The grower mechanic.
children.name: Greater-Of Structure

children.definition: Shared baskets reduce total covenant capacity.
children.name: Shared with RDPs/Investments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 81 (Investments)

children.definition: The cap structure of the general RP basket, expressed as fixed dollar, EBITDA percentage, greater-of formulation, or shared with other covenant baskets.
children.name: Basket Sizing

children.definition: General basket usage requires no event of default to exist (68.8% of corpus). Universal in PC market.
children.name: No EoD Required
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Prevents front-loading of distributions.
children.name: Annual Limitation
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Unused annual capacity carries forward to subsequent fiscal years (4.2% of corpus). Extends effective basket life.
children.name: Carryforward
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 66 (Negative Covenants – carryforward/carryback)

children.definition: KCT cat4.5 requires the protective mechanism 'proceeds down-streaming requirement' but it is not adequately represented in the ontology.
children.name: proceeds down-streaming requirement
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.name: Compliance Testing Timing
children.definition: PIK interest condition includes proceeds down-streaming and compliance timing.
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 27 (Incremental DDTLs)

children.definition: Requirement that PIK interest repayment obligations be current before general basket RP usage. KCT Item 8 risk flag.
children.name: PIK Interest Repayment Condition
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1; KCT Cat 4 Item 6

children.definition: Conditions and restrictions on general RP basket usage including default blockers, annual limits, and carryforward mechanics.
children.name: Usage Conditions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Any event of default blocks general basket usage. Standard in PC market.
children.name: Full EoD

children.definition: Only payment default or bankruptcy blocks general basket usage. Aggressive formulation.
children.name: Payment/Bankruptcy Only
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: General basket usage permitted regardless of default status. Rare and aggressive.
children.name: No Blocker

children.definition: Event of default condition specific to the general basket. Typically requires no default or EoD.
children.name: Default Blocker
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Unused restricted debt payment general basket capacity may be redesignated for RP usage.
children.name: From RDP Basket
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments); Review Template Row 112 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Scope)

children.definition: Unused investment general basket capacity may be redesignated for RP usage.
children.name: From Investment Basket
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 2

children.definition: Capacity flows both directions between RP, RDP, and investment baskets. Most aggressive formulation.
children.name: Bidirectional Reallocation
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Ability to reallocate unused capacity from RDP and/or investment general baskets into the general RP basket, expanding effective RP capacity.
children.name: Reallocation from Other Baskets
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 84 (Other); Review Template Row 92 (Negative Covenants – Investments – General Basket)

children.definition: Fixed-dollar or EBITDA-percentage basket permitting a capped amount of restricted payments for any purpose. Per DLS Preferred: 'subject to no default or event of default continuing or resulting therefrom, a general basket in an amount to be agreed.' Often may be reallocated to make investments or restricted debt payments. Per Learning Material: 'Often includes a grower based on a percentage of EBITDA or Total Assets.' PC Term Comparison: general RP basket and other material RP baskets should be subject to EoD stopper.

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Does not apply to subsidiaries Other Restricted Payment Baskets: (i) unlimited subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (ii) after and IPO 6% per year of IPO proceeds; variations include, (i) any public equity offerings and (ii) a percentage of market capitalization in lieu of or in addition to the IPO/public equity proceeds (iii) excluded contribution (i.e. cash or other qualified contributions not otherwise applied)

Whether RP covenant applies to subsidiaries

negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Applies to equity of Holdings and all of its subsidiaries (i) so long as no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter, customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory, refinancing, subsequent transaction and exit fees (ii) franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence and other overhead expenses of direct and ind

High water marking on grower RP basket — capacity never decreases when EBITDA declines or assets are sold

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket
Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 84(iv): 'subject to no default or event of default continuing or resulting therefrom, a general basket in an amount to be agreed.' Learning Material: 'Often may be reallocated to be used to make Investments or Restricted Debt Payments.' PC Term Comparison: 'General RP basket and other material RP baskets to be subject to EofD stopper.'

children.definition: Ratio-based restricted payment capacity gated by the total net leverage ratio, which measures all funded debt (net of unrestricted cash) against consolidated EBITDA. The most common ratio test for RP baskets (64.4% prevalence), providing a comprehensive view of aggregate leverage. Permits unlimited distributions when pro forma total net leverage falls at or below the specified threshold.
children.name: Total Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Unlimited RPs gated by first lien net leverage ratio (4.4% of ratio baskets). Less conservative than total leverage.
children.name: First Lien Leverage
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 144 (Cushions to first lien)

children.definition: Ratio-based restricted payment capacity gated by the secured net leverage ratio, which measures only debt secured by liens against consolidated EBITDA. Intermediate between the total leverage test (which includes unsecured debt) and the first lien test (which excludes junior liens). Permits unlimited distributions when pro forma secured leverage satisfies the specified threshold.
children.name: Secured Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 4 (b. Funded Debt at Closing); DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans)

children.definition: Ratio-based restricted payment capacity gated by the fixed charge coverage ratio, which measures the borrower's ability to service all fixed obligations (interest, scheduled principal, capital expenditures, and taxes) from operating cash flow. Rare in leveraged credit (more common in ABL facilities) and provides a cash-flow-coverage rather than balance-sheet-leverage gate on distributions.
children.name: Fixed Charge Coverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 73 (b. Covenant)

children.definition: Ratio-based restricted payment capacity gated by the interest coverage ratio, which measures consolidated EBITDA against total interest expense. Uncommon as a standalone gate for restricted payments; when present, typically operates as a secondary dual test alongside a leverage ratio, ensuring both balance sheet leverage and debt service capacity are adequate before permitting distributions.
children.name: Interest Coverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: The financial ratio used to gate unlimited RP capacity. Total net leverage is dominant; first lien and FCCR are alternatives.
children.name: Ratio Test Type
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Conservative ratio test combined with minimum liquidity requirement (e.g., $30M available revolver).
children.name: With Liquidity Requirement

children.definition: Conservative threshold applied specifically to first lien leverage ratio.
children.name: First Lien Specific
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments)

children.definition: Conservative leverage threshold for unlimited RPs, typical in well-covenanted LMM deals.
children.name: 2.0x-3.0x (Conservative)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 104 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – General Basket); Review Template Row 111 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments)

children.definition: Standard threshold level for the total net leverage ratio test gating restricted payment capacity, typically set at the closing-date leverage ratio or 0.25x-0.50x inside closing leverage. The threshold must be satisfied on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the proposed distribution, ensuring that dividends and buybacks do not push leverage above the negotiated ceiling.
children.name: Total Net Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Standard threshold with explicit pro forma compliance requirement after giving effect to the RP.
children.name: Pro Forma Compliance Required
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 9 (Accordion); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Standard leverage threshold for unlimited RPs, representing the market center across CMM and UMM deals.
children.name: 3.5x-4.5x (Standard)

children.definition: Aggressive leverage threshold at 5.0x or higher, common in sponsor-friendly UMM/BSL transactions. Leverage threshold at 6.0x or higher. Market outlier indicating very aggressive RP permissions.
children.name: 5.0x+ (Aggressive)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Greater of a fixed ratio and the opening leverage ratio (e.g., greater of 4.2x or closing TLR).
children.name: Inside Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Fixed ratio test outside (above) closing leverage (e.g., 5.75x when closing is 5.0x).
children.name: Outside Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 73 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – amount)

children.definition: Ratio threshold expressed as a grower pegged to opening/closing date leverage, allowing the test to evolve with deal economics.
children.name: Grower to Opening Leverage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Specific leverage ratio thresholds that gate unlimited RP capacity, ranging from conservative (<3.5x) to aggressive (>5.0x).
children.name: Threshold Levels
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 113 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold); Review Template Row 115 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Ratio test requires leverage to be inside (below) the closing date leverage ratio by a specified cushion.
children.name: Inside Closing TLR
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Alternative test allowing RP if leverage is no worse than immediately before the RP. PC rejects this formulation as it provides a free option.
children.name: No Worse Prong
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 103 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments –); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Ratio basket requiring satisfaction of both a leverage test and a coverage ratio test.
children.name: Dual Test (Inside + Coverage)
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Whether the ratio threshold is expressed as 'inside' (below) or 'outside' (above) the closing date leverage ratio, and whether it uses a 'no worse' prong.
children.name: Inside / Outside Ratio
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Any event of default blocks ratio basket usage, within the unlimited ratio rp basket framework of restricted payments.
children.name: Full EoD

children.definition: Only payment or bankruptcy events block ratio basket usage.
children.name: Payment/Bankruptcy Only
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 15 (Limited Condition Acquisition)

children.definition: Ratio basket usage permitted regardless of default status, subject only to ratio test.
children.name: No EoD Stopper

children.definition: Default blocker applicable to the ratio RP basket, typically requiring at minimum no payment/bankruptcy default.
children.name: EoD Stopper

children.definition: Unlimited restricted payment basket available when a specified leverage test is satisfied on a pro forma basis. Per Learning Material: 'Typically based on a leverage test (typically Total Net Leverage Ratio) set at a level significantly below the closing date level.' PC Term Comparison: UMM Aggressive 1.0-1.75x inside closing leverage with EoD stopper; CMM/LMM 1.0-2.5x inside closing leverage with EoD stopper.

children.definition: Small annual cap typical in LMM deals with modest management equity plans.
children.name: $500K-$1M (Small)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 113 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Threshold)

children.definition: Standard annual cap representing the market center across CMM deals.
children.name: $1-3M (Standard)

children.definition: Large annual cap typical in UMM deals with significant management equity programs.
children.name: $3-5M+ (Large)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 115 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Ratio Basket)

children.definition: Per-fiscal-year cap on management equity repurchases, typically expressed as fixed dollar amount or EBITDA percentage.
children.name: Annual Dollar Cap

red_flags.text: Management equity repurchase basket exceeds $50M or 50% of EBITDA without annual cap reset — disproportionate sponsor recovery path

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 74 (Negative Covenants – Indebtedness – Ratio Debt – non-guarantor cap); Review Template Row 103 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments –)

children.definition: A cap (e.g., $5M lifetime) independent of annual usage.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Aggregate
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 79 (a. Indebtedness)

children.definition: Aggregate cap expressed as a multiple of the annual cap (e.g., 2x or 3x the per-FY amount).
children.name: Multiple of Annual Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 126 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees)

children.definition: No lifetime aggregate cap; annual cap is the sole constraint. More common in BSL.
children.name: No Aggregate Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 126 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees)

children.definition: Cumulative dollar ceiling on restricted payments used to repurchase equity interests from current or former management, directors, and employees. Limits total leakage through management buybacks over the life of the facility, typically with an annual sub-limit and a separate lifetime cap that may include carryforward of unused annual amounts.
children.name: Aggregate Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 126 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees)

children.definition: Management equity basket sized as a percentage of EBITDA rather than or in addition to a fixed dollar cap. Creates a grower mechanic.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage Alternative
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); Review Template Row 42 (Asset Sale Sweep - Threshold)

children.definition: Unused annual capacity carries forward one fiscal year only, capped at 2x the annual amount.
children.name: One-Year Carryforward

children.definition: Unused capacity accumulates indefinitely. Aggressive formulation common in BSL.
children.name: Unlimited Carryforward
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 103 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments –); Review Template Row 105 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Ratio Basket); Review Template Row 107 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Unrestricted Subsidiary Stock)

children.definition: Restriction preventing unused annual management repurchase capacity from rolling into subsequent years. Without carryforward, the borrower loses any portion of the annual basket not utilized within each fiscal year, creating a use-it-or-lose-it dynamic that limits back-loaded management buyback activity in later years.
children.name: No Carryforward

children.definition: Capacity from future years may be borrowed against current-year needs. Rare and aggressive.
children.name: Carryback Permitted

children.definition: Rules for carrying unused annual management equity capacity to subsequent fiscal years.
children.name: Carryforward Mechanics

children.definition: Higher or uncapped repurchase rights upon death or disability of management, typically funded by key person insurance proceeds.
children.name: Death / Disability

children.definition: Carveout from the management repurchase basket permitting the borrower to withhold or repurchase equity interests to satisfy tax obligations arising from the vesting or exercise of equity awards. These payments are economically necessary to prevent employees from bearing unfunded tax liabilities on compensation, and are typically uncapped or subject to a separate, more generous limit.
children.name: Tax Withholding
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); Review Template Row 110 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Permitted Tax Distribution)

children.definition: Carveout permitting the deemed repurchase of equity interests in connection with cashless exercises of stock options, where the exercise price is satisfied by surrendering a portion of the underlying shares rather than paying cash. No cash actually leaves the borrower, so this carveout prevents a non-cash transaction from consuming the dollar-limited management repurchase basket.
children.name: Cashless Exercise

children.definition: Carveout permitting repurchase of equity interests from departing employees, officers, or directors upon termination of employment or service. Typically subject to an annual sub-limit or aggregate cap and covers mandatory repurchase obligations in shareholder agreements triggered by death, disability, retirement, or involuntary termination.
children.name: Employment Termination
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases)

children.definition: Repurchases funded by key person life insurance proceeds, typically uncapped to the extent of insurance recovery.
children.name: Key Person Insurance Proceeds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA); DLS Preferred Row 78 (Affirmative covenants)

children.definition: Specific circumstances where management equity repurchases are permitted outside the standard annual/aggregate caps.
children.name: Special Purpose Carve-Outs
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 109 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Management Agreement)

children.definition: Whether administrative agent consent is required for management equity repurchases exceeding the standard annual cap.
children.name: Agent Consent for Overages
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 14 (Delayed Draw Term Loans); DLS Preferred Row 60 (a. Lender Selection)

children.definition: Basket permitting repurchase of equity interests held by directors, officers, employees, managers, and consultants upon death, disability, retirement, or termination. Per Learning Material: 'Typically a dollar amount per year, which increases following an IPO. Typically unused amounts may be carried forward to subsequent years. Often increased by proceeds of equity issued to directors/employees (such proceeds would not also increase the Builder Basket) and proceeds of key person life insurance.' PC Term Comparison: 'Avoid carry backs and limit carryforwards to one year. Include EoD stopper.'

children.name: Management Equity Repurchases

key_negotiation_points: Ratio type for unlimited RP basket
Whether RP covenant applies to subsidiaries
negotiation_spectrum.market_position: Market standard for restricted payments reflects a negotiated middle ground, with specific terms varying by deal size, leverage profile, and competitive dynamics.
negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Applies to equity of Holdings and all of its subsidiaries (i) so long as no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter, customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory, refinancing, subsequent transaction and exit fees (ii) franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence and other overhead expenses of direct and ind

red_flags.text: Management equity repurchase basket exceeds $50M or 50% of EBITDA without annual cap reset — disproportionate sponsor recovery path

children.definition_source: Learning Material Section (7)(3): 'Typically a dollar amount per year, which increases following an IPO.' PC Term Comparison: 'Management buyback carrybacks and carryforwards: Avoid carry backs and limit carryforwards to one year. Include EofD stopper.'
pc_ref: : 'Management buyback carrybacks and carryforwards: Avoid carry backs and limit carryforwards to one year. Include EofD stopper.'

children.definition: Standard formulation allowing 6% per annum of net cash proceeds from the first qualified IPO.
children.name: Standard 6% Annual
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Six percent of net cash proceeds from the first qualified IPO per annum.
children.name: 6% (Market Standard)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 3 (Debt Quantum); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 116 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Refinancings)

children.definition: Eight percent of net cash proceeds. Typically paired with market cap component in BSL deals.
children.name: 8% (Aggressive)
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Non-standard percentage negotiated on a deal-specific basis.
children.name: Variable / Negotiated

children.definition: The percentage of net IPO cash proceeds permitted as annual distributions. 6% is market standard; 8% is aggressive.
children.name: IPO Proceeds Percentage
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount); DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting)

children.definition: Market cap percentage as the sole test for post-IPO RPs, without IPO proceeds component.
children.name: Standalone Market Cap Test
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 58 (Financial Covenant – levels); Review Template Row 96 (Negative Covenants – Dispositions); Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases)

children.definition: Market cap percentage added to IPO proceeds percentage for maximum post-IPO RP capacity.
children.name: Combined with IPO Proceeds
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Subjective valuation determined by borrower in good faith.
children.name: Market Cap Component
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 116 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – Refinancings)

children.definition: Separate carve-out for public company costs (SEC filings, D&O insurance, auditor fees) not counting against post-IPO RP basket (2.3% of corpus).
children.name: Public Company Costs Carve-Out
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Whether an event of default blocks post-IPO RP usage. Some deals do not subject post-IPO baskets to any default blocker.
children.name: EoD Stopper

children.definition: Restriction limiting post-IPO basket to common stock dividends only, excluding preferred dividends or equity repurchases.
children.name: Common Dividends Only
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Provisions addressing IPO baskets in the context of SPAC or de-SPAC transactions, which may trigger IPO-related RP capacity.
children.name: SPAC / De-SPAC Provisions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (o. Voting); Review Template Row 114 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Debt Payments – General Basket)

children.definition: Typically in private credit deals where IPO is not anticipated.
children.name: No IPO Basket
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 103 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments –); Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket)

children.definition: Basket available after a qualifying IPO permitting annual restricted payments equal to a percentage of IPO proceeds (typically 6%) or market capitalization. Per Learning Material: 'a basket available after a Qualifying IPO permitting an amount of RPs per year equal to a percentage of IPO proceeds (typically 6%).' PC Term Comparison: 'Highlight for client if it is the sum of proceeds and market cap. Highlight if it includes post-IPO public offering proceeds (should accept), private issuances (will likely reject), or SPAC provisions.'

annual dividends up to a percentage of IPO proceeds

red_flags.text: IPO proceeds RP basket permits distributions from subsequent equity offerings without leverage condition

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket

children.definition_source: Learning Material: 'a basket available after a Qualifying IPO permitting an amount of RPs per year equal to a percentage of IPO proceeds (typically 6%).' DLS Preferred row 84 alt: 'after an IPO 6% per year of IPO proceeds.' PC Term Comparison: 'Post-IPO basket: Highlight for client if its the sum of proceeds and market cap.'

children.definition: Tax distributions calculated at the highest combined federal, state, and local marginal tax rate applicable to any holder.
children.name: Highest Marginal Rate

children.definition: Tax distributions capped at a specified fixed rate (e.g., 40%) regardless of actual holder tax rates.
children.name: Fixed Rate Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 82 (d. Permitted Acquisitions); Review Template Row 19 (Swingline)

children.definition: Tax distributions limited to actual tax liabilities of holders. Most conservative formulation.
children.name: Actual Holder Rate
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 72 (a. EBITDA)

children.definition: Maximum assumed tax rate for computing permitted tax distributions (typically highest combined marginal rate).
children.name: Tax Rate Cap
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); Review Template Row 19 (Swingline); Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases)

children.definition: Tax distributions include tax benefits from stepped-up basis. Conservative position that prevents excess distributions.
children.name: Includes Step-Up Amortization
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); Review Template Row 138 (Pricing)

children.definition: Tax distributions calculated without regard to stepped-up basis benefits. Aggressive formulation that allows larger distributions than actual tax liability.
children.name: Ignores Step-Up Amortization
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments)

children.definition: Whether tax distributions account for or ignore stepped-up basis depreciation/amortization, which can significantly inflate distribution amounts.
children.name: Stepped-Up Basis Treatment
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios)

children.definition: Permitted distributions covering estimated income tax payments owed by equity holders of pass-through entities (LLCs, partnerships, S-corporations) on their allocable share of the borrower's taxable income. Calculated using an assumed maximum combined federal and state tax rate, these distributions prevent equity holders from bearing unfunded tax liabilities on income they have not actually received.
children.name: Estimated Tax Payments
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments)

children.definition: Year-end reconciliation of estimated tax distributions versus actual tax liabilities, with clawback or credit provisions.
children.name: True-Up Mechanics

children.definition: Tax distribution basket applicable only when the borrower or parent operates as a pass-through entity (LLC, LP, S-Corp).
children.name: Pass-Through Structure Only
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Permitted distributions to cover taxes of equity holders in pass-through structures and overhead expenses of parent entities. Per DLS Preferred: 'customary tax distributions in respect of the consolidated, combined or similar income taxes attributable to the taxable income of Holdings/the Borrower.' Per Learning Material: 'Should be narrowly limited to amounts attributable to the ownership of the company. Tax amounts can potentially be very large and should be reviewed carefully.' PC Term Comparison warns about 'advantageous treatment to sponsors of ignoring enhanced depreciation/amortization tax deductions from stepped up basis in assets.'

expressly permits ignoring amortization of stepped up basis in assets

children.definition: Small annual holdco expense cap typical in LMM deals.
children.name: Under $1M
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Standard holdco expense cap representing market center.
children.name: $1-2M
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Large holdco expense cap typical in UMM/BSL deals with significant corporate overhead.
children.name: Over $2M
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Per-fiscal-year cap on distributions to Holdings for operating expenses, typically $0.5-2M.
children.name: Annual Cap
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Fees payable pursuant to the management agreement in effect on the closing date, subject to amendment restrictions.
children.name: Per Management Agreement

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Management Agreement

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5; Review Template Row 109 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Management Agreement)

children.definition: Separate carve-out for one-time transaction fees payable to sponsors in connection with acquisitions, dispositions, or refinancings.
children.name: Transaction Fee Carve-Out
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 33 (Alternate transaction fee); KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Fee payable upon termination of the management agreement, typically triggered by IPO or change of control.
children.name: Termination Fee
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 32 (Ticking fee); DLS Preferred Row 35 (Administration fee); DLS Preferred Row 38 (Termination date); KCT Cat 4 Item 5; Review Template Row 14 (Term Sheet)

children.definition: Annual management, monitoring, and advisory fees payable to private equity sponsors under management agreements.
children.name: Sponsor Advisory/Management Fees
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

RP_MANAGEMENT_FEE.label: Restricted Payments - Management Fees
exactPhrases: payments allowed by reference to management agreement
sponsor management agreement as in effect on the closing date
amendments not materially adverse to lenders
sectionHeaders: Transactions with Affiliates - Sponsor Management Fees

exactPhrases: payments allowed by reference to management agreement
sponsor management agreement as in effect on the closing date
amendments not materially adverse to lenders

children.definition: Requirement that management fees, monitoring fees, or advisory fees paid to the sponsor or its affiliates be subordinated in right of payment to the credit facility obligations. Subordination may take the form of payment blockage during an event of default, deferral and accrual provisions, or an absolute cap on aggregate fees payable during the term of the facility.
children.name: Fee Subordination Agreement
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Whether holdco expense distributions are subject to any event of default blocker.
children.name: EoD Stopper
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Restriction on amending the management agreement to increase fees without lender consent.
children.name: Amendment Restriction
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 5

children.definition: Permitted distributions for franchise taxes required to maintain corporate existence, overhead expenses of parent entities attributable to the borrower, and sponsor management fees. Per DLS Preferred: 'franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence and other overhead expenses of direct and indirect parents thereof.' Also covers sponsor advisory, monitoring, refinancing, subsequent transaction, and exit fees under management agreements, subject to no default/EoD. PC Term Comparison: management fees should be capped and subject to a default/EoD blocker.
children.name: Holdco Operating Expenses / Management Fees

negotiation_spectrum.aggressive_position: Does not apply to subsidiaries Other Restricted Payment Baskets: (i) unlimited subject to compliance with a total leverage ratio and no default or event of default (ii) after and IPO 6% per year of IPO proceeds; variations include, (i) any public equity offerings and (ii) a percentage of market capitalization in lieu of or in addition to the IPO/public equity proceeds (iii) excluded contribution (i.e. cash or other qualified contributions not otherwise applied)

negotiation_spectrum.preferred_position: Applies to equity of Holdings and all of its subsidiaries (i) so long as no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter, customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory, refinancing, subsequent transaction and exit fees (ii) franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence and other overhead expenses of direct and ind

red_flags.text: Holdco operating expense / management fee basket exceeds 2% of revenue with no board approval requirement

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases
Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Management Agreement
Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 84(i)-(ii): 'customary exceptions for distributions necessary to pay Sponsor advisory, refinancing, subsequent transaction and exit fees... franchise and similar taxes required to maintain corporate existence.' PC Term Comparison: 'Management fees should be capped and subject to a D/EoD blocker.'

children.definition: Any event of default under the credit agreement blocks all restricted payments. Most conservative; standard in PC market.
children.name: Full Event of Default
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 7

children.definition: Only payment defaults (missed interest/principal) and bankruptcy/insolvency events trigger the RP blocker. Permits distributions during covenant defaults.
children.name: Payment Default / Bankruptcy Only
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 7; KCT Cat 5 Item 3

children.definition: Blocker triggered only by specified categories of events of default, typically excluding cross-default, judgment, and ERISA events.
children.name: Specified EoD Only
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 57 (Specified Representations)

children.definition: Basket usage permitted regardless of default status. Most aggressive; flagged as high-risk by institutional committees.
children.name: No Default Blocker
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 84 (f. Restricted Payments); DLS Preferred Row 85 (g. Restricted Debt Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 86 (h. Available Amount)

children.definition: Classification of the default condition that triggers the RP blocker.
children.name: Blocker Type

children.definition: Default blocker applies to all RP baskets without exception.
children.name: Universal (All Baskets)
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Default blocker applies to most baskets but carves out tax distributions, holdco expenses, or other operational payments.
children.name: With Carve-Outs
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Which RP baskets are subject to the dividend blocker. Some baskets (e.g., tax distributions) may be carved out.
children.name: Basket Scope
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: How the dividend blocker interacts with equity cure rights. Whether an equity cure that remedies a financial covenant default also lifts the RP blocker.
children.name: Cure Interaction
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 3 Item 1

children.definition: Whether dividend payments to affiliates must satisfy the affiliate transaction covenant's arm's-length and board-approval requirements in addition to RP basket availability. Captures the cross-covenant linkage where affiliate distributions face dual qualification hurdles.
children.name: Affiliate Transaction Qualification

review_ref.term: Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold

children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1; Review Template Row 124 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates –); Review Template Row 125 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – De Minimis Threshold)

children.definition: Whether the existence of a maintenance financial covenant (springing or fully tested) mitigates dividend blocker concerns by providing an ongoing performance check. Deals with maintenance covenants may permit broader RP flexibility because the covenant itself constrains distributions during stress.
children.name: Maintenance Covenant Mitigant
children.definition_source: KCT Cat 4 Item 1

children.definition: Default and event-of-default conditions that block restricted payment usage across all baskets. The scope of the blocker ranges from full EoD (all 14+ categories) to payment/bankruptcy only to no blocker at all. Per PC Term Comparison: 'General RP basket and other material RP baskets to be subject to EofD stopper; for TTS Transactions Clients may accept bktcy/payment EoD.' Per DLS Preferred row 84: 'no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing before or thereafter.' The blocker scope is a critical negotiation dimension that significantly affects lender protection during stress.

children.definition: Distributions of equity or debt of unrestricted subsidiaries, a key leakage channel. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Raise with Clients ability to dividend Unrestricted Subs. This is considered leakage and can be round tripped to build contribution debt or other RP capacity. Will likely be rejected even in Aggressive UMM/BSLR; as a compromise discuss blocking cash cow Unrestricted Subs.' Per DLS Preferred row 92: preferred position is 'No ability to designate unrestricted subsidiaries.' Per KCT Cat 4 Item 2: unlimited investments in unrestricted subsidiaries without reference to baskets or ratios is a risk escalation item.

children.definition: Mechanism allowing returns on investments to be reclassified as available for RP usage, creating a recycling loop.
children.name: Trap Door Mechanics

INV_TRAP_DOOR.label: Investments - Trap Door Protection
exactPhrases: Includes J Crew Trap Door language
Includes J Crew Trap Door language

children.definition: Whether the investment return basket is subject to J.Crew restrictions on investments in unrestricted subsidiaries.
children.name: J.Crew Blocker Interaction
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 69 (Negative Covenants – J Crew protection)

children.definition: Risk that investments in unrestricted subsidiaries generate returns that are then distributed as RPs, extracting value through two covenant channels.
children.name: Double-Dip Risk
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 67 (Unrestricted Subsidiaries - generally); Review Template Row 71 (Negative Covenants – double dip); Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases)

children.definition: Restricted payments funded from returns on permitted investments -- the 'trap door' or recycling mechanism. Per Learning Material: 'Returns on investments made using the primary RP builder prong, often capped at the amount of the original investment.' Returns include dividends, distributions, interest, principal repayment, sale proceeds, and FMV of redesignated unrestricted subsidiaries. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Typically will seek to cap returns on investment type baskets to amount of original investment. Avoid allowing for double counting returns.' The investment return path creates a recycling loop: RP capacity -> Investment -> Returns -> AA Growth -> RP capacity again.

RP_AVAILABLE_AMOUNT.label: Restricted Payments - Available Amount Basket

distributions up to the Available Amount

children.definition: Restricted payments from mandatory prepayment proceeds declined by lenders, allowing the borrower to dividend out amounts that lenders chose not to accept. Per DLS Preferred row 70 alt: 'Declined proceeds shall be retained by the Borrower and build the Available Amount.' Per Learning Material: 'Declined Proceeds are commonly added to the Builder Basket, which is available for restricted payments, restricted debt payments and investments.' If a second lien exists, 'the borrower typically is required to offer to prepay the second lien term loans' before the declined proceeds build the AA.

red_flags.text: Declined ECF sweep proceeds automatically credited to Available Amount without leverage test — bypasses mandatory prepayment protection

children.definition_source: DLS Preferred row 70 alt: 'Declined proceeds build the Available Amount.' Learning Material Section (4): 'Declined Proceeds commonly added to Builder Basket.'

children.definition: Annual restricted payment basket sized as a fixed dollar amount rather than a formula based on earnings or leverage metrics. Provides certainty of distribution capacity regardless of financial performance fluctuations, making it particularly valuable in cyclical industries where EBITDA-linked baskets may contract during downturns.
children.name: Fixed Dollar Amount
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 13 (Leverage Ratios); DLS Preferred Row 70 (Mandatory Prepayments); DLS Preferred Row 79 (a. Indebtedness)

children.definition: Annual cap as a percentage of Consolidated EBITDA.
children.name: EBITDA Percentage

children.definition: Per-fiscal-year ceiling on restricted payments made under the annual RP basket, providing a predictable rhythm of permitted equity distributions independent of leverage ratios or builder basket accumulation. The annual cap resets each fiscal year and may include carryforward provisions for unused capacity.
children.name: Annual Cap
children.definition_source: Review Template Row 106 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Employee Stock Repurchases); Review Template Row 108 (Negative Covenants – Restricted Payments – Post-IPO Basket); Review Template Row 126 (Negative Covenants – Transactions with Affiliates – Sponsor Management Fees)

Per Learning Material, this is distinct from the builder basket approach. More common in BSL than private credit. Per PC Term Comparison, annual baskets are typically subject to EoD stoppers. May include carryforward provisions allowing unused amounts to be carried to subsequent periods.

Per Learning Material, these are categorized as restricted payments within the holdco expenses/tax distribution carve-out framework. Usually uncapped but limited to amounts that mirror declared dividends. A structural carve-out rather than a basket.

children.definition: Ability to redesignate or reclassify restricted payments across covenant categories (RP, RDP, Investments). Per Learning Material: 'In some deals, the company may later reclassify an RP from one basket to another. For example, an RP that previously was made under a dollar basket can later be moved to the ratio basket, which frees up the dollar basket for future use.' Per Learning Material example: 'the Company will be entitled to divide or classify (or later divide, classify or reclassify in whole or in part in its sole discretion) such Restricted Payment among such clauses.' PC Term Comparison: 'Other than in Aggressive UMM/BSLR transactions, reject reallocations to build debt capacity.'

Prevents the borrower from being forced to rescind a properly authorized distribution.

children.definition: Additional permitted restricted payment baskets covering specific transaction types, operational needs, and miscellaneous distributions. Per Learning Material, common examples include: dividends payable solely in qualified equity interests, distributions by non-wholly-owned subsidiaries on pro rata basis, intercompany distributions up the chain to the borrower, equity cures applied as distributions, and distributions in connection with permitted acquisitions. These stand outside the primary RP baskets and typically operate as structural carve-outs.

children.definition: Restriction prohibiting the borrower entity from repurchasing its own equity interests (as distinct from parent or holdco buybacks). When present, limits equity retirement to the holding company level and prevents direct cash leakage from the credit party group, maintaining borrower-level liquidity for debt service.
children.name: Not Permitted
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 82 (Permitted Acquisitions)

children.definition: Whether debt repurchased by the borrower retains voting rights or is deemed cancelled for voting purposes.
children.name: Voting Restrictions
children.definition_source: DLS Preferred Row 93 (Voting)

children.definition: Ability of the borrower to repurchase its own debt in the secondary market. Per PC Term Comparison: 'Make Clients aware if non pro rata open market purchases/privately negotiated purchases are permitted. Require Borrower/subs to cancel debt acquired. D/EofD stopper. Cap at 25/30%. No revolver draw. No vote/cap vote at 49.9% for debt fund affiliates. Try to cap number of Affiliated Lenders to avoid block on class vote.' Creates both credit and control dynamics as sponsor-affiliated purchasers may accumulate blocking positions.

market_data.dominant_pattern: Not permitted or pro rata only

children.name: Borrower Debt Buybacks

red_flags.text: Borrower debt buyback basket permits open market purchases at discount without pro rata offer to all lenders

children.definition_source: PC Term Comparison: 'Require Borrower/subs to cancel debt acquired. D/EofD stopper. Cap at 25/30%. No revolver draw. Cap vote at 49.9% for debt fund affiliates.'
pc_ref: : 'Require Borrower/subs to cancel debt acquired. D/EofD stopper. Cap at 25/30%. No revolver draw. Cap vote at 49.9% for debt fund affiliates.'

definition: The negative covenant governing distributions of value from the credit group to equity holders and affiliates. Restricted payments include dividends and distributions on account of equity interests, repurchases and redemptions of equity interests, and payments to parent entities. The covenant is structured as a general prohibition followed by enumerated exceptions (carve-outs for unlimited exceptions and baskets for capped exceptions). Scope generally applies to the borrower and restricted subsidiaries; per DLS Preferred it 'applies to equity of Holdings and all of its subsidiaries.' Leakage through RP is the most direct form of value transfer out of the credit group -- cash flows up to the sponsor or equity holders.
